update.description:
issue #780

This pull request adds `ActuatorPlugin`, a model plugin that enforces a torque limit on a joint based on its current velocity.

Included also is an example in `examples/stand_alone/actuator`. To run:

```
cd <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make install
./actuator
```

This will run an experiment that attempts to command a constant torque on two models that are identical except one uses `ActuatorPlugin` and the other does not.

To plot the data collected from this experiment, use the plotting script provided (matplotlib needed):

```
python <gazebo path>/stand_alone/actuator/data/plot.py
```

There is one known issue, which is that if a force exceeding the maximum torque for an actuated joint is commanded on the first timestep of simulation, the actuated joint won't enforce the torque-speed curve on that timestep. I think that this problem is hard to fix while this feature remains a plugin but easy to fix if it is incorporated into the main physics library.

![actuator_torque_time_actuated.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2113990264-actuator_torque_time_actuated.png)
![actuator_torque_speed_actuated.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4070651820-actuator_torque_speed_actuated.png)
update.title: Actuator plugin (torque-speed curve for joints)

content.raw: Thanks. I'll merge this, with the intention to deprecate it after we finish the work on actuators in the physics library.
content.html: Thanks. I'll merge this, with the intention to deprecate it after we finish the work on actuators in the physics library.

update.title: Actuator plugin (torque-speed curve for joints)

content.raw: I think this is a great prototype. We can move discussion to a design document as we figure out how to build actuators into the gazebo physics class.
content.html: I think this is a great prototype. We can move discussion to a design document as we figure out how to build actuators into the gazebo physics class.

content.raw: Currently `plot.py` assumes `data.csv` is in the current working directory.
content.html: Currently plot.py assumes data.csv is in the current working directory.

content.raw: If the speed is above the allowed limit, should the maximum torque be set to zero?
content.html: If the speed is above the allowed limit, should the maximum torque be set to zero?

update.title: Actuator plugin (torque-speed curve for joints)

content.html:
right.... I have been thinking about how to redesign this because I don't love how it works right now.

class Actuator
{
  // properties
  float power;
  float maxVelocity;

  // commanded state
  float velocity;

  // actuator model
  boost::function<float (Actuator* actuator)> modelFunction;

  // the joint we are actuating
  Joint joint;

  // interface functions
  // input is torque from joint member
  // calls a generic function
  public: void SetCommandedVelocity
  (
    // Side effect of the motor model: set joint torque based on outcome
    float torque = this->modelFunction(this);
    ...
  );
};

BUT that line where I call the model function is kind of terrible. It may be more prudent to take a more OOP approach: make Actuator an abstract class, and make the motor model a pure virtual function that gets implemented by subclasses representing different motors.

would be nice to define the arguments of this boost function. We could paste from the .cc file:

/// \param[in] float1 Input velocity.
/// \param[in] float2 Input torque.
/// \param[in] ActuatorProperties Static properties of this actuator
/// \return Torque according to the model.

We could also consider defining an ActuatorState class, if we wanted to consider position as well as velocity. Then the function could have two arguments.

content.raw:
Can you change the example so that it doesn't install models? Include all the SDF in the example world file is fine.

We shouldn't install things into the gazebo models directory because it may overwrite an existing model.
content.html:
Can you change the example so that it doesn't install models? Include all the SDF in the example world file is fine.

We shouldn't install things into the gazebo models directory because it may overwrite an existing model.
